instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02016: What is 820-02016? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2337: What is A2337? A2337 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2020 M1 with EMC 3598, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-02016..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2337</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) with 5V and 0.02-4 A on both USB-C ports.

- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> = 11.80-12.25V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> = 3.8V
- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> = Missing
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> = Missing
- <SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> = Missing
- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> = Missing
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC0_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
- <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC0_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 1.5V
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC1_LDO</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
- <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC1_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 1.5V
- <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_AON_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> (without battery) = 4.1-5.1V

I noticed when the MacBook is fully assembled a clicking noise at the CPU/Audio board area.

Is the firmware bad? (When I turn on the MacBook - fully assemebled - it doesnt go into recovery/DFU automatically) - So I assume the firmware is good?

Edit: Not possible to get it into DFU mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Any history available?

Check diode mode to ground on secondary power rails.
Compare with good board, or refference table.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://openboarddata.org/?a=showboardsolutions&bpath=laptops/apple/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>[/URL]

Do you get LDOs voltage from <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Board looks clean and the previous owner told me he that he close the MacBook and on the next day it stopped working. (no boot)

- <SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL> = 0.287
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> = 0.447
- <SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL> = 0.268
- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL> = 0.330

I have checked the following:
- <SIGNAL>PP1V4_LDO_PREREG</SIGNAL> = Missing / 0.291
- <SIGNAL>PP1V5_VLDOINT_MPMU</SIGNAL> = 1.45V
- <SIGNAL>PP1V8_AON_MPMU</SIGNAL> = 1.8V
- <SIGNAL>PPVDD_PMU_LDO_PREREG</SIGNAL> = Missing / 0.291
- <SIGNAL>USBC0_3V3LDO_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.525
- <SIGNAL>USBC1_3V3LDO_EN</SIGNAL> = 0.527

- <SIGNAL>P5VS2_EN</SIGNAL> = Missing / 0.368
"<SIGNAL>P5VS2_EN</SIGNAL> is produced by the PMU, <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
A missing enable signal can mean <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> is bad, or there is a communication issue with <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and the SOC/other components. A firmware issue can also * *likely* cause missing enable signals from PMICs on the M1 machines. As of 1/14/2022, this remains rare."
Source: [URL]https://repair.wiki/index.php?title=A2337_2020_MacBook_Air&mobileaction=toggle_view_desktop[/URL]

So maybe the firmware is bad? Because the diode reading of the enable signal is good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
I expected output voltages.

Try again on page 34; <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> (SYM 3 OF 6).
There are 3 LDOs to check, all other NC; also check <SIGNAL>VREF_ADC</SIGNAL>.
You've posted only one!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
- <SIGNAL>MPMU_VREF_ADC</SIGNAL> = Missing / 0.559

Which LDOs are missing? I can't find any LDOs (without NC) - could you please help me out. (im on page 34)

threads.message:
What about <SIGNAL>1V2_S2</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL>?
How did you find <SIGNAL>1V8_AON_MPMU</SIGNAL>, but no other?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
- <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S2</SIGNAL> = Missing / 0.336
- <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL> = Missing / 0.447

Clicking noise is coming from "<TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>" - When I connect the battery and USB-C cable (for charging) the values are 5V / 0.36A - <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR> is getting hot.

I have already replaced it - no short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> after doing the same (battery charging cable etc.) the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is back again (only when battery is connected) - Any idea? Clicking noise is also back again .... even with a new <TRANSISTOR>Q5800</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Checking diode mode with power applied (battery connected)???
How could you have short if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> are generated?

<CHIP>U8100</CHIP> is suspect, if doesn't generate all necessary LDOs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Ok not the battery is causing the "short" - only happends when the audio board is connected.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> (with audio board connected) = 8.1V / Diode mode says "OL" (measured while turned off - not connected to charger/battery)
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> (without audio board connected) = 12.26V

I think I will order a new PMU IC (<CHIP>U8100</CHIP> / 343S00438).

Edit: I have removed the short from the audio board - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is now on 12.26V with audio board connected. (Clicking noise is gone)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
I have replaced the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is now on 1V â€¦.

Output USB-C: 5V / 0.04A

threads.message:
You've did something wrong in the process.
Or <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> is bad...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot

Hmm IC looks good and perfectly soldered - I will re-do my work.

Edit: After re-do same result - so I guess the IC is faulty because <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is looping between 0.9 and 1.1V â€¦ I hope I will get a refund (source: AliExpress)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message: Could it be that the "enable" signal is missing for the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>? If so what's the name? <SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
I have re-soldered the original PMU IC .... <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is still looping between 0.9 and 1.1V - what the ... ?

The following are missing ....
- <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> / 0.320
- <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> / 0.565
- <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> / 0.598

<CHIP>U5200</CHIP> is good - Will be <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> generated when <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is at 0.9 - 1.1V?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is the mother of all voltages from MLB; apart of <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> LDOs.

Did you test the board alone on the desk?
You had <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> before.
Something happened when you've cgahnged <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>; maybe heat affected other components.

Post <CHIP>U5200</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDD/P, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Yes I have tested it without anything connected. (no audio board etc.)

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_AON_CHGR_R</SIGNAL> = 5.0-5.1V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 1.2V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> = missing / 0.580
<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_VDDA</SIGNAL> = 5.0-5.1V
<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL> = 5.0-5.1V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> = missing / 0.591
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> = missin / 0.592

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
A/BMON look too high, if <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is not present.
Check resistance over <CAPACITOR>C5220</CAPACITOR>/60.
Remove F5200 and check <CAPACITOR>C5254</CAPACITOR> voltage.

"<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> = missing"
Why do you think that?
Looks good for me; if really no voltage there...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5220</CAPACITOR> = 0.520
<CAPACITOR>C5260</CAPACITOR> = 0.580
F5200 removed / <CAPACITOR>C5254</CAPACITOR> = 0.9-2.5V (looping)

Yeah true ... its a reset signal - sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message: I meant resistance OVER the mentioned caps; between their pins, not to ground!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5220</CAPACITOR> = 2.3 ohms
<CAPACITOR>C5260</CAPACITOR> = 180k ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5260</CAPACITOR> = 180k ohms"
Fix the problem!
Check <RESISTOR>R5261</RESISTOR>/62 and their traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
My fault other way around â€¦
<CAPACITOR>C5220</CAPACITOR> = 180k ohms
<CAPACITOR>C5260</CAPACITOR> = 2.3 ohms

so <RESISTOR>R5222</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5221</RESISTOR> right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message: Yes, check them...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message:
Fixed - <RESISTOR>R5222</RESISTOR> was blown replaced it now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is back on 12.27V.

I noticed that <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL> is just at 2.8V (too low) instead of 3.8V.

Step 1. Check for a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V8_AON_VDDMAIN</SIGNAL>. <CAPACITOR>C5887</CAPACITOR> is a good place to measure from. Normal diode mode to ground reading = ~.350.
- Value: 0.313

Step 2. Check the enable signal to <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>P3V8_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>.
- <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> = 5V
- <SIGNAL>CHGR_MVR_EN</SIGNAL> = 5V

Step 3. Ensure that the VIN (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL>) is making to <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>. Occasionally a via or trace can break resulting in a voltage not making it to some parts of the board. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> can be measured adjacent to <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>, on <CAPACITOR>C5704</CAPACITOR> or <CAPACITOR>C5804</CAPACITOR>.
- <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> (12.27V) is present on those two caps.

If all above findings are negative for issues, replace <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>.
- Should I proceed with that step or do you have any other idea?

----------------

I might have (accidentally) touched <SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PVCC</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> with my multimeter (<SIGNAL>P3V8AON_PVCC</SIGNAL> is now 0.085) - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_AON</SIGNAL> is going from 3V-12V ... I think it's time to replace the <CHIP>U5700</CHIP>....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message: The M1 processor may be dead now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02016</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - 5V / 0.02-4 A - No boot
threads.message: Remove them and check if diode mode on <SIGNAL>3V8_AON</SIGNAL> goes high.
